20th July 188[8]
The final digit is uncertain; our reading is based on the fact that William Denton, whose death is mentioned in the letter, died in 1888.

Your last letter reached me yesterday. I have posted you some numbers of my paper the Cooktown Courier which I am now editing in the hope that I shall obtain a command of some expedition to New Guinea yet. [Kemp's] Gold find in New Guinea is a glaring lie. He never found the 6oz specimen there. If people go there with him, they will surely rue it, mark my words. As for the Geographical Society's party I have already told you what I think. Now they actually intend to land in the Mai Cussar river where Capt Strachan & his party shot the natives!
John Strachan with four companions entered the Mai Kassa River, Papua, in May 1884 and engaged in much fighting with the local people before withdrawing to Saibai Island. Did you ever hear of such madness. It is nothing less than suicide. Nothing will come of this expedition except disappointment & waste of money. — If the Melbourne men are so anxious to try the Island for Gold, I shall be glad to lead an expedition for them. I only require two things. Firstly they must pay my wife a certain monthly sum sufficient to keep her in comfort, and secondly I must have a personal interview in Melbourne with the parties and be allowed to inspect & purchase every article which goes with the expedition. I only want two miners & perhaps a geologist might be induced to accompany me. The cost for 8 months would not exceed £1,500 to £2000. The heaviest item would be the trade — tobacco beads, salt, hatchets, chisel irons, etc. My arms must be the best procurable not necessarily for fighting, but in case of accidents.

You know I have never had a disagreement with the natives yet & I have been farther than even the missionaries. They acknowledge this themselves. I know there is gold & probably in heavy deposits. The natives called it Jari & said there was plenty, but I abstained from writing about it, as I have been so long on gold fields that I fully appreciate the immensity of the crime of causing a rush, anywhere & especially to such a place as I allude to. Not that there is any danger to a small party. I experienced none & will go there again if necessary. Professor Denton was distinctly of opinion that we should find heavy deposits of gold at the junction of the slate and granite. Unfortunately his illness & death frustrated our schemes. We were in black & grey slate, talchose schist, a greasy sort of stuff crossed by numerous veins of Quarts & this formation was under the Volcanic breccia of Mt Astrolabe.
Part of Astrolabe Ranges, Papua.?
In fact the summits of the highest ranges were volcanic breccia while their bases were as above.

If you choose to hand this letter to any of the people who are anxious to test the Island for gold you are at liberty to do so and I am prepared to fulfil my word. I do not say there is heavy gold but that I believe heavy deposits exist not far from where I turned back & I have Denton's opinion to support me.

We are having exceptionally wet weather just now. I have asked Mr Page who left for Port Moresby yesterday to collect all interesting plants he may discover on the slopes of Owen Stanly
Owen Stanley Range, Papua. where he is cutting Cedar. You can imagine how I envy him. How I wish I had means to go in by myself.
